Award.AwardTitle: Maximizing Collective Impact Through Cross-Sector Partnerships: Planning a SENCER and NISE Net Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Center for Science and Civic Engagement (NCSCE) will conduct a Collaborative Planning project to maximize the collective impact of two well-established national STEM learning networks, National Informal STEM Education Network (NISE Net) and Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities (SENCER). Through a strategic collaboration that leverages their respective achievements, resources, and expertise, the combined networks can advance informal science education that engages and empowers citizens and their communities as they address the complex civic challenges. The project will conduct a strategic planning process to envision how to unify two networks to increase a durable and identifiable infrastructure for cross-sector collaboration focused on linking science and civic engagement. It is supported by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings, as a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments.

The project objective of the planning process is to create a new and expanded national infrastructure that will increase the capacity of science centers and other informal learning organizations to enhance the public's engagement with science through attention to civic issues, and access new partners, participants, and resources from higher education institutions. The project's core activity will be a three-stage planning process: Phase 1, an assessment of assets, resources, and regional complementarity of the networks, and the development and investigation of key research questions; Phase 2, a planning workshop involving 29 project leaders from both organizations and stakeholders from formal and informal science to identify and develop specific collaborative strategies; and Phase 3, an evaluation and dissemination of the planning results to the networks and the development of a new multi-year project to strengthen the national infrastructure for formal and informal STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As an outcome from this project, both SENCER and NISE Net are taking initial steps towards the goal of strengthening institutional capacity and STEM-learning infrastructure through partnerships. NISE Net will support an upcoming SENCER-ISE proposal, and its publication on civic engagement is providing a foundation for future work. SENCER has also initiated discussions with several other national informal learning organizations that participated in the project regarding potential joint STEM-related projects.

The project’s survey of formal and informal STEM practitioners has yielded valuable information regarding receptivity towards partnerships that SENCER will be using in future SENCER-ISE projects. SENCER undergraduate faculty, for example, expressed strong interest in engaging with the pedagogies, program formats, and venues for informal STEM learning. In addition to responding to the formal survey, many sent personal emails further indicating the depth of their desire to participate in new SENCER-ISE collaborations.

At the workshop, leaders of major national network organizations spanning the informal and formal science sector were able to meet, exchange ideas, share best practices, and begin exploring potential collaborations. From those discussions, the group reflected on  the indispensable characteristics of successful network collaborations. These were: building relationships individually and institutionally, effective communications, clear roles and responsibilities, sufficient funding, agreed-upon goals, and a shared purpose. The representatives of participating organizations individually and collectively examined their shared purposes, and what specific goals could form the basis of a partnership, and their organization’s readiness and potential to enter into a network collaboration.

The results of this grant have been disseminated to communities of interest in a variety of ways. Articles were published in the Science Education and Civic Engagement International Journal and the Informal Learning Review. Sessions at the SENCER Summer Institute 2017 were devoted to addressing lessons learned from this grant, along with related SENCER-ISE projects. SENCER e-news was used to reach a broader audience and to identify a wider range of participants working on cross sector partnerships, including National Park Service collaborations. The survey portion of this grant went to more than 3,000 individuals in the SENCER, NISE Net, and ASTC communities, a number that expanded as recipients forwarded it to colleagues.
